questions.question_text:
A user's computer is displaying a black screen. The technician restarts the computer, but the OS still does not load. The technician discovers the OS was patched the previous evening.
Which of the following should the technician attempt NEXT?

choices.C: Configure boot options in the BIOS
choices.A: Reboot into safe mode and roll back the updates

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
the OS was patched the previous evening'> answer is always to rollback something. In this case it is the OS

The technician discovers the OS was patched the previous evening is the key phrase it was a corrupt update will not change the boot sequence. You need to boot to safe mode and do a system restore before the os was patch
If the computer displays a black screen and the OS does not load, how can he boot into safe mode? I think C is the right thing to do NEXT.

comments.content: Admittedly it is a jump in logic but I took “does not load the OS” to mean there is no complaint about the BIOS.

The typical troubleshoot to an issue after an update is to revert the last update and in this case the other options doesn't have too much sense. But you are right on what you mention, the question itself doesn't have too much logic because it doesn't specify in which step the computer screen gets blank and this is a critical info to troubleshoot. In any case my advise is to go with the base logic of revert the update.

discussion.content: GPS is a prime suspect for battery consumption acknowledged by CompTIA. Not only does GPS have a high battery drain but it is constantly working if not disabled. They have other exam questions which directly state this too. Correct answer is GPS.

comments.content: It also mentions heat issues... Display brightness is a main cause of this.

Actually I am going to offer a reason that Brightness could be correct. Firstly, it is set to auto, so the phone will increase the brightness during the day (highest while outside but also moderate while in a bright room etc) which dramatically increases power consumption. Secondly, the screen autolock is set to off. This means that the screen will constantly be on and adjusting brightness higher unless the user turns it off. This would indeed drain the battery extremely fast and could be lessened most effectively by manually setting the brightness.

discussion.content:
This has to be A. Privacy > Maps.

B says Display > Brightness so we can disregard the Auto-Lock setting because we've gone a level past that in the menu.

Also if you look in the usage, Maps has used 3.2GB of data. That is definitely excessive, especially compared to the other statistics.
this should be privacy setting and display setting it is both bad for battery, a phone that never locked that's is a no no, and a map that is always active even close no no.
B is the best answer
this person has 15gb of photos.. what in the world is he doing with so much pictures?

comments.content: I think the key phrase in this question is feels warm to the touch, yes GPS would drain your battery but I don't think it make your phone warm to the touch, it has to be brightness because of autolock never

discussion.content: If there was an option for auto lock NEVER I'd pick that but since it's not an option, I'm gonna have to say A based on the information in the settings, but again brightness could be linked to auto lock never so.... there are 2 correct answers, this question sucks

Selected Answer: A
The answer is A. It is all about 'reading comprehension' The giving answer for A is Privacy maps. Therefore you should ONLY look at 'Maps always'. Some of people are talking about 'Auto-lock Never and Night-mode' but answer B ONLY states about Display 'Brightness' and not about the other options like auto-lock and night-mode. So don't make it too complicated.
A is the correct answer, no doubt.
My iphone got hot with the screen unlocked though keeping Maps on did not. I will go for B.

Two key details:
1) Maps usage: 3.2 GB (super high)
2) Privacy settings: Maps - Always
Correct option: A
How can it be brightness if the issue persists when the phone is put away?

comments.content: and also the night mode is disable.

discussion.content: Display is correct. Auto lock being set to never is the key here

Any person that has ever used a smart phone, ever, knows that Maps, even set as background app, or minimized, are huge power hogs and will make your phone hot, and drain your battery quick. The display brightness has nothing to do with it, Autolock could be an answer, but it was not an option. 
Answer is A.

Answer should be A.
It mentions that the battery still drains "even after it is put away".
Therefore brightness cannot be the correct answer.
A.Privacy – Maps

comments.content: Go ahead if you want to get it wrong since you know better.
It's not the site it's the actual answers... they are completely bogus! For an "entry" test the way its written is awful.

discussion.content:
its privacy, maps. 
how many other wrong answers are on this site? lol i'm gonna fail the darn test

I don't agree with this answer, The brightness option is set to auto and we are talking about a new phone, no meaning to overheat or lose battery because of this. Even if the Auto-Lock option is set to -Never- it doesn't mean the display will not turn-off automatically because that is the "sleep" option. 
On the other hand the Maps App in the privacy setting is set to -Always- and the usage show 3.20GB of data consumption. Heavy usage of 4G + Location (GPS) is a big load even for modern mobile devices capable to heat the phone as described and drain a battery in less than one day.

comments.content: Most of the previous comments mentioned this. I wonder what happened to them.

Just because the privacy setting is set to "Always" doesn't mean the maps app is "Always" running. But if you think you know better than A+ be my guest and get the question wrong. The answer is B Display settings. "Auto Lock Never" is a hint. Also in A+ study guides screen brightness is a major cause of phone over heating.

questions.question_text:
A Windows user is attempting to install a local printer and is unsuccessful based on permissions.
Which of the following user types BEST describes this user?

comments.content: First of all, in the question is doesn't mention about a SOHO or a larger institution. I am literally on my pc as a 'standard user' and I am able to install a local printer??? Please don't make it to difficult for other learners.

discussion.content: This should be standard user. It is unlikely a SOHO or a larger institution with a domain is using a guest account for users. They would more use that maybe in lobbies or as a quick kiosk type activity. Guest user is disable by default. The normal user would be a standard user. Standard users cannot install software and cannot install specifically printers/drivers for a printer without also being part of the admin group.
it saying based on permission. Guest cannot install or delete so is unsuccessfully. Guest is correct answer.

Selected Answer: A
Standard users and Guest users can't install applications on the system, so they aren't able to install printer driver needed by the printer. Nevertheless a standard user can add a local printer triyng it with general windows driver, so the answer is "guest user".
https://answers.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/forum/all/standard-user-account-able-to-install-programs/16681a59-b271-4499-82f8-4bf131a4981e
in an enterprise env there is no guest accounts, correct answer is standard user.

comments.content: The question didn't mention enterprise environment. It stated "windows user."
welcome to comptia
Someone who will eventually need a tech lol
Yes, that is messed up.
50% of home users use without anti-virus ==, expense they think
You must be new here, ROOKIE
Too many ROOKIES
might be Joe or Ann

discussion.content: The answer makes sense, but the question is, who is using a system without anti-virus, though?
mostly this happens after visiting you-know-what video sites....hehehe
@Landy360, hör auf ständig Leute in den Kommentaren zu beleidigen. Das ist weder hilfreich noch anständig.
the answer comptia is looking for is B. install an anti-malware software. However, it could also be that the Pop Up blocker in Internet Options under security has been disabled.

comments.content: under Privacy rather.
The computer is also running slow... If he has malware how would a popup blocker be a solution? He needs anti virus to get rid of it..

questions.question_text:
An end user is browsing the Internet when multiple browser pages open by themselves. The user notices the PC is running slowly, even while not browsing the
Internet.
Which of the following actions should the user take?

discussion.content: Preboot execution environment (PXE), pronounced pixie, is a set of standards that enables a computer to load an operating system (OS) over a network connection. ... It may also be called PXE boot, boot from network, network boot or local area network boot. PXE can greatly simplify large deployments of computers.

questions.question_text:
A desktop technician is attempting to upgrade several machines to Windows 10. After realizing there is only one disc for the installation, the technician decides to upgrade over the network.
Which of the following boot methods initiates such an upgrade?
